bibl.title: Letter from John P. Felt to International Health Board, April 4, 1923

div1.p: Felt reports on a possible yellow fever case in West Africa.

div1.head: Letter from John P. Felt to International Health Board, April 4, 1923
div1.opener:
COPY
I. H. B
Africa
JOHN P. FELT
126 State Street
Boston 2, April 4, 1923
International Health Board
61 Broadway
New York City
Dear Sirs:
div1.p:
Referring to the correspondence passed with reference to
yellow fever serum and vaccine desired by my West African correspondents.

The following information has been received and is forwarded
for your records:

“Under date February 2, 1923 the agent of the Cie. Francaise de
l'Afrique Occidentale located at Saltpond, Gold Coast
Colony, British West Africa, advises that a European lady
died at Saltpond of yellow fever and, according to cable,
received by my correspondents' head office on February 21,
1921, new cases of this epidemic have been ascertained
amongst the native population.”

The foregoing information has been forwarded by the Cie. Francaise
de l'Afrique Occidentale with headquarters at 32 Cours Pierre Puget, Marseille,
France.
